level1.e1:
The dir command will print our a list of all the files and subfolders contained in a folder.

The formatting for the command is as follows:
DIR [drive:][path][filename] [/A[[:]attributes]] [/B] [/C] [/D] [/L] [/N]
  [/O[[:]sortorder]] [/P] [/Q] [/R] [/S] [/T[[:]timefield]] [/W] [/X] [/4]

  [drive:][path][filename]
              Specifies drive, directory, and/or files to list.

  /A          Displays files with specified attributes.
  attributes   D  Directories                R  Read-only files
               H  Hidden files               A  Files ready for archiving
               S  System files               I  Not content indexed files
               L  Reparse Points             O  Offline files
               -  Prefix meaning not
  /B          Uses bare format (no heading information or summary).
  /C          Display the thousand separator in file sizes.
              This is the default.  Use /-C to disable display of separator.
  /D          Same as wide but files are list sorted by column.
  /L          Uses lowercase.
  /N          New long list format where filenames are on the far right.
  /O          List by files in sorted order.
  sortorder    N  By name (alphabetic)       S  By size (smallest first)
               E  By extension (alphabetic)  D  By date/time (oldest first)
               G  Group directories first    -  Prefix to reverse order
  /P          Pauses after each screenful of information.
  /Q          Display the owner of the file.
  /R          Display alternate data streams of the file.
  /S          Displays files in specified directory and all subdirectories.
  /T          Controls which time field displayed or used for sorting
  timefield   C  Creation
              A  Last Access
              W  Last Written
  /W          Uses wide list format.
  /X          This displays the short names generated for non-8dot3 file
              names.  The format is that of /N with the short name inserted
              before the long name. If no short name is present, blanks are
              displayed in its place.
  /4          Displays four-digit years
level1.e2:
Primarily used for changing the current directory. entering the command with no options can display the current directory.

CHDIR [/D] [drive:][path]
CHDIR [..]
CD [/D] [drive:][path]
CD [..]

  ..   Specifies that you want to change to the parent directory.

Lets say we were in the user folder, displayed as:

C:/Users/CLIME

and inside that folder are subfolders:
Desktop
Documents
Downloads
Favorites
Google Drive
Links
Music
OneDrive
Saved Games
Searches
Videos

If we want to change our directory to the OneDrive folder, we would write the command:

cd Onedrive
-or-
chdir OneDrive
level1.e3:
/? Displays help at the command prompt. This can come in handy when you want to run a command but are unsure of the options that are available, or are typing a command but it gives you an error.

NOTE: Don't confuse this with "HELP", which is a command that shows all basic Command Prompt Utilities.
level1.e4:
The tree command displays the the folder structure of a drive or path graphically. While it may seem like a basic command, it gives the user a visual idea of what the folder structure may look like rather than using other commands such as dir /s which would show all the contents line-by-line.

Formatting for the command is as follows:
 TREE [drive:][path] [/F] [/A]

   /F   Display the names of the files in each folder.
   /A   Use ASCII instead of extended characters.
level1.e5:
The tree command displays the the folder structure of a drive or path graphically. While it may seem like a basic command, it gives the user a visual idea of what the folder structure may look like rather than using other commands such as dir /s which would show all the contents line-by-line.

Formatting for the command is as follows:
 TREE [drive:][path] [/F] [/A]

   /F   Display the names of the files in each folder.
   /A   Use ASCII instead of extended characters.

level2.e1:
The mkdir command is used to create a directory.

MKDIR [drive:]path
MD [drive:]path

Let's assume we're in the directory C:/Users/CLIME and we wanted to make a new directory called Charlie. To do this we would type the following command:

mkdir Charlie

This would create a new folder (with no contents) on the Desktop.

Now we can use dir to verify it has been created:

C:\Users\CLIME>dir /b
Charlie
Contacts
Desktop
Documents
Downloads
Favorites
Music
OneDrive
Searches
Videos
level2.e2:
The rmdir command is used to remove a directory.

The format is as follows:

RMDIR [/S] [/Q] [drive:]path
RD [/S] [/Q] [drive:]path

    /S      Removes all directories and files in the specified directory
            in addition to the directory itself.  Used to remove a directory
            tree.

    /Q      Quiet mode, do not ask if ok to remove a directory tree with /S

If a directory is not empty it will give the message "The directory is not empty.". If you want to delete the folder and its contents, use the /S option (NOTE: this will ask you to confirm your deletion). If you want to delete the entire directory tree, you can add the /Q and it will remove the directory without prompting you.
level2.e3:
As the name implies, move is acommand used for moving files and directories from one location to another. Additionally, this command can be used to rename files and directories.

To move one or more files:
MOVE [/Y | /-Y] [drive:][path]filename1[,...] destination

To rename a directory:
MOVE [/Y | /-Y] [drive:][path]dirname1 dirname2

  [drive:][path]filename1 Specifies the location and name of the file
                          or files you want to move.
  destination             Specifies the new location of the file. Destination
                          can consist of a drive letter and colon, a
                          directory name, or a combination. If you are moving
                          only one file, you can also include a filename if
                          you want to rename the file when you move it.
  [drive:][path]dirname1  Specifies the directory you want to rename.
  dirname2                Specifies the new name of the directory.

  /Y                      Suppresses prompting to confirm you want to
                          overwrite an existing destination file.
  /-Y                     Causes prompting to confirm you want to overwrite
                          an existing destination file.

level3.e1:
The ping command sends packets of data to specific IP addresses and lets you know how long it took to send the data and recieve a response. Among other uses, the ping command can help IT admins troubleshoot a network problem.

The command format is as follows:

ping [option]

Options:
    -t             Ping the specified host until stopped.
                   To see statistics and continue - type Control-Break;
                   To stop - type Control-C.
    -a             Resolve addresses to hostnames.
    -n count       Number of echo requests to send.
    -l size        Send buffer size.
    -f             Set Don't Fragment flag in packet (IPv4-only).
    -i TTL         Time To Live.
    -v TOS         Type Of Service (IPv4-only. This setting has been deprecated
                   and has no effect on the type of service field in the IP
                   Header).
    -r count       Record route for count hops (IPv4-only).
    -s count       Timestamp for count hops (IPv4-only).
    -j host-list   Loose source route along host-list (IPv4-only).
    -k host-list   Strict source route along host-list (IPv4-only).
    -w timeout     Timeout in milliseconds to wait for each reply.
    -R             Use routing header to test reverse route also (IPv6-only).
                   Per RFC 5095 the use of this routing header has been
                   deprecated. Some systems may drop echo requests if
                   this header is used.
    -S srcaddr     Source address to use.
    -c compartment Routing compartment identifier.
    -p             Ping a Hyper-V Network Virtualization provider address.
    -4             Force using IPv4.
    -6             Force using IPv6.

Additionally, you can make sure the network interface of your computer (wifi or ethernet adapter) is working by pinging 127.0.0.1
level3.e2:
ipconfig is a command line tool used to control the network connections to your PC. This command can also be used to assist IT admins troubleshooting network problems.

Options:
       /all             Display full configuration information.
       /release         Release the IPv4 address for the specified adapter.
       /release6        Release the IPv6 address for the specified adapter.
       /renew           Renew the IPv4 address for the specified adapter.
       /renew6          Renew the IPv6 address for the specified adapter.
       /flushdns        Purges the DNS Resolver cache.
       /registerdns     Refreshes all DHCP leases and re-registers DNS names
       /displaydns      Display the contents of the DNS Resolver Cache.
       /showclassid     Displays all the dhcp class IDs allowed for adapter.
       /setclassid      Modifies the dhcp class id.
       /showclassid6    Displays all the IPv6 DHCP class IDs allowed for adapter.
       /setclassid6     Modifies the IPv6 DHCP class id.


Typing ipconfig without parameters displays only the IP address, subnet mask and
default gateway for each adapter bound to TCP/IP.

Examples:
    > ipconfig                       ... Show information
    > ipconfig /all                  ... Show detailed information
    > ipconfig /renew                ... renew all adapters
    > ipconfig /release *Con*        ... release all matching connections,
                                         eg. "Wired Ethernet Connection 1" or
                                             "Wired Ethernet Connection 2"
    > ipconfig /allcompartments      ... Show information about all
                                         compartments
    > ipconfig /allcompartments /all ... Show detailed information about all
                                         compartments
level3.e3:

Options:
       /all             Display full configuration information.
       /release         Release the IPv4 address for the specified adapter.
       /release6        Release the IPv6 address for the specified adapter.

       /flushdns        Purges the DNS Resolver cache.

       /displaydns      Display the contents of the DNS Resolver Cache.
       /showclassid     Displays all the dhcp class IDs allowed for adapter.
       /setclassid      Modifies the dhcp class id.
       /showclassid6    Displays all the IPv6 DHCP class IDs allowed for adapter.
       /setclassid6     Modifies the IPv6 DHCP class id.


Typing ipconfig without parameters displays only the IP address, subnet mask and
default gateway for each adapter bound to TCP/IP.

Examples:

    > ipconfig /renew                ... renew all adapters
    > ipconfig /release *Con*        ... release all matching connections,
                                         eg. "Wired Ethernet Connection 1" or
                                             "Wired Ethernet Connection 2"
    > ipconfig /allcompartments      ... Show information about all
                                         compartments

                                         compartments
